title: POLITICO Pro Canada: Climate heats up as Canadian campaign issue, to a degree
text:
canada POLITICO Pro Canada: Climate heats up as Canadian campaign issue, to a degree

Avec Tyler Weyant

QUICK FIX

Story Continued Below

— A majority of Canadian voters surveyed in an exclusive POLITICO/Abacus Data poll say they’re “very” or “extremely” concerned about climate change. But Canadians are far from aligned on which specific energy and climate policies to back.

— The blackface scandal that rocked the election conversation has not yet realigned the race. An aggregate of surveys shows the top two parties still tied.

— While Prime Minister Justin Trudeau and Foreign Affairs Minister Chrystia Freeland fight for their political survival above the 49th parallel,a team of old political hands will represent Canada at the U.N. General Assembly this week.

C’EST LUNDI — Welcome to POLITICO Pro Canada’s morning newsletter, where Lauren is heading out to Vancouver Island for the day. Send news tips and song requests for our Spotify playlist to lgardner@politico.com, apanetta@politico.com and cboudreau@politico.com, or on Twitter @Gardner_LM, @Alex_Panetta and @ceboudreau.

“Give my best to the mess I've had my fill of it / And give my worst to the curse I've had my fill of it”

DRIVING THE DAY

FIRST FOR PRO: HOW CLIMATE ISSUES STACK UP WITH VOTERS — Climate change continues to register as a top issue for Canadian voters this election season, with a solid majority in the latest POLITICO/Abacus Data poll saying they’re very worried about it.

Still, they weren’t nearly as decisive when asked questions that drill down on various climate and energy policy approaches and goals. Opinions are largely split on regional and party lines, Lauren reports this morning.

“The data just confirmed how divisive some of these issues and how regionalized they are,” Abacus CEO David Coletto said.

— Main takeaways: As one might expect, respondents from Western Canada were largely in favor of building more pipelines and expanding the oil industry, while Quebecers were mostly opposed. British Columbia voters were evenly split, and Ontarians’ responses tracked with national opinion.

There was no clear national consensus on the carbon tax, while a modest plurality of those surveyed — 41 percent — said Canada should build more pipelines.

Coletto noted quite a few voters didn’t have a strong opinion one way or the other on energy and climate issues. While Canadians generally support the domestic energy industry, many don’t appear to be as fervent about backing the sector as voters who live in the oil patch itself, he said.

— How views could evolve: The data also show a strong correlation between voters’ support for a carbon tax and whether they think climate change is a serious issue for government to address, Coletto said.

“As more and more Canadians become concerned about climate change, it’s likely that fewer and fewer will be supportive of keeping [the oil] industry going and keeping status quo public policy on it,” he said.

— NDP on climate: New Democratic Party leader Jagmeet Singh announced Sunday that his government would more than double disaster mitigation funds to communities grappling with the effects of extreme weather events that scientists say will become more commonplace.

Singh announced the plan in Gatineau, Que., which has faced flooding so severe in recent years that the provincial government has bought out some residents to compel them to live elsewhere.

AT THE RACES — Trudeau’s Liberal Party and the Conservative Party remain tied at 34 percent, according to an aggregate of polls.

That's nearly identical to last week's results, which had the Liberals down by one point. The other parties haven’t picked up much support, either.

Trudeau’s party still has a subtle advantage in the regional breakdown of the votes: It holds a 15-point lead in Quebec and a five-point lead in Ontario -- the two provinces with the most seats.

— Watching for other surprises: Coletto told Alex that the scandal’s initial impact appears minimal, but that could change. One reason it could still matter is the race is so close, he said, and any individual event could ultimately prove decisive in a neck-and-neck battle.

Another factor to keep in mind is international reaction. Canadians are sensitive to the way their country is perceived, and they prize its reputation for tolerance, Coletto said.

Thus, the scandal could affect Canadians as they see the story picked up by major international outlets. “When Donald Trump is surprised by this and commenting on it, you know it’s gone beyond [Canada],” Coletto said.

— Stand by me: Freeland lent her voice last week to the chorus of support Trudeau’s received from his Cabinet, saying Friday she had confidence in his leadership despite being “troubled and disappointed” by the images. That’s notable given her high visibility in Trudeau’s government.

— More blackface admissions: Green Party leader Elizabeth May acknowledged Saturday that one of the party’s candidates in Newfoundland and Labrador admitted to wearing blackface once in a comedy sketch broadcast on the CBC nearly 30 years ago. May said the incident “falls in a different category” because the skit “wasn’t a hidden video.”

— Peeling back the curtain: “Inside the charity gala where Justin Trudeau shocked 500 guests with blackface,” from The Telegraph of U.K.

WEEKEND ROUNDUP — Here’s a quick look at what the major party leaders were touting on the stump over the weekend:

— Liberals: After taking Saturday off, Trudeau announced on Sunday his plan to exempt from taxes the first $15,000 per year earned by “middle-class Canadians.” He also pledged to lower cell phone bills by encouraging more wireless competition.

— Conservatives: Leader Andrew Scheer outlined a plan on Sunday in Charlottetown, P.E.I., to better deliver pensions and benefits to Canadian veterans.

— NDP: Aside from making a climate announcement, Singh didn’t rule out working with Liberals in a minority government, despite the brownface scandal. And Singh said Friday he’d entertain a meeting with Trudeau to discuss racism, as long as it happened behind closed doors. On Saturday, he promised health and dental benefits to part-time and contract workers.

— Greens: Leader Elizabeth May vowed Saturday in Winnipeg to decriminalize street drugs like methamphetamines and heroin.

CANADA AT THE U.N. — It’s customary for Canadian politicians to eschew travel abroad during formal campaign periods, so Ottawa is instead sending a team of veteran government hands to New York for UNGA’s 74th session.

— Who’s who: Deputy Minister of Foreign Affairs Marta Morgan will lead the delegation, which includes former prime ministers Jean Chrétien and Joe Clark; former Quebec premier Jean Charest; and Sen. Peter Boehm. Boehm served as Trudeau’s sherpa when he hosted the G-7 in Charlevoix, Que., in 2018, an event memorable for President Donald Trump’s Twitter diatribe upon his exit.

Climate change is expected to be a major issue at the global confab this week. POLITICO’s Anthony Adragna and Ryan Heath provide readers a guide on what to watch for as other countries grapple with how to handle the U.S.’ lack of leadership when it comes to global warming.

— Want more on UNGA? Read POLITICO’s U.N. Playbook here.

NORTHERN EXPOSURE

— Lawyers for Huawei’s CFO Meng Wanzhou will begin eight days of hearings today, seeking access to documents related to her detention and arrest at Vancouver's airport. Documents they filed with the court also argue that Trump is using their client as a bargaining chip in the trade war. CBC.

— Texas real estate agents and local governments are stepping up efforts to lure Canadian oil services businesses to the U.S. by promising tax incentives and cheap land. The Canadian Press.

— Florida’s two Republican senators have proposed legislation allowing Canadian “snowbirds,” which contribute billions to their state’s economy, to stay in the U.S. for two additional months per year. The Associated Press.

— New York state energy officials said Canadian hydropower would be examined as part of a mandate to hit 70 percent renewable energy by 2030. Allowing subsidies for importer hydropower would be a boon for the Champlain Hudson Power Express, a decade-old plan to bring power from HydroQuebec to New York City. POLITICO Pro.

— The U.S. Department of Agriculture released last week a report analyzing Canada’s beef and pork market, noting heavy declines in cattle alongside increases in swine. The report indicates Chinese bans on beef and pork will still hurt the market. USDA.

— Thousands more Canadian GM employees were furloughed as supply chains remained dormant during the UAW strike in the U.S. Union officials indicated 700 more workers could be laid off temporarily at a St. Catherine’s, Ont., plant. CNBC.

ON THE CALENDAR

Noon — The Cato Institute holds a book discussion on "The Three Languages of Politics," focusing on progressives, conservatives and libertarians.1000 Massachusetts Ave. NW, Washington.

12:30 p.m. — The Council on Foreign Relations holds a discussion about the role of the Homeland Security Department and the challenge of immigration in the United States. 1777 F St. NW, Washington.

Did we miss an event? Let us know at canadacalendar@politicopro.com.
